reference.title: Pip Verification Commands
reference.shortdesc: This topic provides commands to verify if pip, the Python package manager, is correctly installed and up-to-date on your system.

section.title: Overview
section.p: Verifying pip installation is essential to ensure you can install and manage Python packages. The following table provides commands to check pip installation, version, and update status across different platforms.

strow.stentry: Checks if pip is installed and displays the installed version.
The pip version number, e.g., pip 21.1.2
Alternative command to check pip version using Python.

A list of installed packages and their versions.

A success message confirming pip is upgraded.

section.title: Troubleshooting Pip Installation
section.p: If pip is not installed, you may see an error message indicating that the command was not found. In this case, follow the instructions below:

ul.li: Windows: Download and install the latest version of Python from the official Python website. Ensure that "Add Python to PATH" is selected during installation.
macOS: Install pip using sudo easy_install pip or by installing Python via Homebrew.
Linux: Use the package manager for your distribution, e.g., sudo apt install python3-pip for Debian-based systems.

section.title: Additional Resources
section.p: For more information on pip commands, visit the official pip documentation.
